#Text=Crosshaven
#Text=Crosshaven ( Irish : Bun an Tabhairne ) is a village in western County Cork .
#Text=History
#Text=Originally a Viking settlement , Crosshaven eeked out an existence as a fishing village until the 18th century when it became a British garrison town .
#Text=Crosshaven House , formerly the residence of the local Squires , The Hayes Family was built in the same period .
#Text=In the late 19th century a convent and school were built , along with the Catholic and Anglican churches , and the Grand Hotel .
#Text=In the early 20th century , tourism became important to the town 's economy with the arrival of the train and the new fashion for visiting beaches .
#Text=Around this time the Majorca Ballroom was built .
#Text=In 1938 the British left Crosshaven and control of the forts passed to the Free State Army .
#Text=After the war the train service was discontinued and though the spread of private cars brought other destinations to within reach of Cork residents , the town remained popular with tourists .
#Text=In 1966 , The Royal Cork Yacht Club , which claims to be the oldest in the World , having been established in Cobh in 1720 , moved across the harbour to Crosshaven .
#Text=Around the same time , the " Slobland " , an area of silt in front of Crosshaven house was filled in to become a car park .
#Text=In the 1970s and 2000s
#Text=Crosshaven experienced two construction booms which caused a massive increase in population .
#Text=The even more explosive growth in the population of Carrigaline , 8km closer to Cork City , inhibited its growth as a commercial centre .
#Text=Crosshaven has a reputation for being bourgeois , partly as a result of the presence of the Yacht Club , but in reality has a fairly broad population demographic .
#Text=Orientation
#Text=Coming from Cork City , the Yacht Club is passed on the left and the Grand Hotel on the right .
#Text=Most of the shops , pubs and restaurants are on Lower Road and The Square , from which two roads lead to the beaches at Graball and Church Bay .
#Text=Another road leads from behind The Grand Hotel to the beaches at Myrtleville , Fennel 's Bay and Fountainstown .
#Text=By car or bicycle
#Text=The R612 leads from Cork City to Crosshaven through Carrigaline , which can be bypassed .
#Text=The distance is 19km and takes 35 minutes by car , longer at peak times .
#Text=If travelling by bicycle , the last 5km can be cycled along a pleasant pathway by The Owenbwee River and Drake 's Pool .
#Text=By public transport
#Text=Regular busses run from the Main Bus Station in Cork City .
#Text=By boat
#Text=The Boatyard offers a place for sailors to dock their boats .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Unless You are travelling to the beaches , the best way to get around is on foot .
#Text=Walking trails also lead to some of the beaches .
#Text=See
#Text=Fort Camden , Camden Rd , ☏ +353858501483 .
#Text=Built in 1780 , this fort was built to protect the strategically important commercial centres of Cork City and Cobh .
#Text=Spectacularly located overlooking the Harbour with views of Cobh , Spike Island , Little Island and Fort Carlisle , it has undergone restoration and is open to tourists in the summer months .
#Text=Templebreedy .
#Text=The church that gives the parish its name dates from the 14th century .
#Text=Only the ruins remain but it was used as a graveyard until the late 20th century .
#Text=Crosshaven House .
#Text=Built in the 18th century to house the Hayes Family , it passed into the hands of Community Association in 1973 though has subsequently become a private residence again .
#Text=However , the two outhouses remain in Community hands and the grounds are used as a pitch and Putt Club .
#Text=Anglican Church .
#Text=Designed by William Burges , the architect of St Finbarr 's in Cork , but on a much more modest scale .
#Text=Do
#Text=Royal Cork Yacht Club .
#Text=Every two years it hosts Cork Week , described as the " biggest fun Regata in the World " .
#Text=The Boat Yard and Marina ( on the other side of town ) .
#Text=Offer non-members of the yacht club a place to dock their boats .
#Text=In the 1970s a boat was built using only technology available in medieval times in an attempt to prove that St Brendan , a 6th century Irish saint was able to sail to what is now Newfoundland .
#Text=Swim
#Text=Graball ( approximately 1km from the village ) .
#Text=The site of a swimming club in the past , it offers quiet , safe bathing in an atmosphere of faded grandeur .
#Text=Church Bay ( approximately 1km from the village ) .
#Text=Divided in Victorian and Edwardian times into " The Men 's Pool " and " Ladies Bay " , it 's a safe and comfortable place to swim and to dive .
#Text=Fennel 's Bay ( around 2km from the village , near TempleBreedy ) .
#Text=Its relative remoteness make it a quite spot .
#Text=Myrtlevile ( 3km from the village ) .
#Text=Also the site of Pine Lodge and Bunnyconellen .
#Text=Its clear sands make it a very popular spot in Summer .
#Text=Fountainstown ( around 4km away ) .
#Text=Also a sandy beach that can become crowded in summer .
#Text=Walk
#Text=Crosshaven has walks for every level of fitness .
#Text=A gentle walk leads from the village to Drake 's Pool , where according to a local apocryphal tale , Francis Drake hid while fleeing from the Spanish Armada .
#Text=Another walk leads from the village to Castlepoint and up a gentle slope known locally as " The Grassy " to Fort Camden , from where a spectacular view of the Harbour can be enjoyed .
#Text=It 's possible to continue from here to Graball , where there 's a modest beach , and from there to Church Bay .

#Text=It 's possible to walk from here to Fennel 's Bay along the Rcoks , though only when the tide is more than half-way out ( check for tide times ) and by people with reasonable rock climbing skills .
#Text=Those that brave this route are rewarded with excellent views of the harbour and a chance to visit the remains of World War I gun turrets and look-out posts .
#Text=An alternative is to walk from Church Bay up a steep hill to TempleBreedy , the church that gives Church Bay its name , and from there to Fennel 's Bay .
#Text=The walk from Fennel 's Bay to Myrtleville is unchallenging .
#Text=The entire walk from the village to Myrtleville takes around 2 or 3 hours .
